    spatialGE: Guide to spatial heterogeneity analysis in melanoma (Thrane et al. 2018) spatialGE: Kriging for Visium data sets spatialGE: Reading GeoMx-DSP outputs Troubleshooting

    deconv_krige: Spatial interpolation of gene expression deconvolution scores

    deconv_krige.Rd

    Performs spatial interpolation ('kriging') of cell scores from gene expression deconvolution scores.

    Usage

    deconv_krige(
  x = NULL,
  cells = "top",
  univ = F,
  res = NULL,
  who = NULL,
  method = "xcell",
  python = T
)

    Arguments

    x

    an STList with transformed xCell scores.

    cells

    a vector of cell names or 'top'. If 'top' (default), kriging is estimated for the 10 cells with highest standard deviation for each spatial arrays.

    univ

    a logical stating whether or not to perform universal kriging. Default is FALSE (ordinary kriging).

    res

    a double to adjust the resolution of the plot. Fractions of 1 lead to more resolution, but longer run times. Default is 0.5 for Visium ST arrays.

    who

    the spatial arrays for which kriging will be performed. If NULL (Default), all arrays are kriged.

    method

    the method from which deconvolution scores will be taken from. The default is 'xCell' and the only method supported (for now).

    python

    a logical, whether or not to use the Python implementation. If FALSE, geoR is used.

    Value

    x, an STList including spatial interpolations.

    Details

    This function takes a STList and a vector of xCell cell names and performs spatial interpolation ("kriging") of deconvoluted cell scores. It also calculates spatial heterogeneity statistics. The function can perform ordinary or universal kriging. If cells='top', then the 10 cell types with the highest standard deviation for each tissue array are interpolated. The function supports kriging via the Python package PyKrige or geoR. The first option is faster but requires a Python environment to be set up.

    Examples

    # In this example, melanoma is an STList.
# melanoma <- deconv_krige(melanoma, cells=c('b_cells', 'i_dc'), who=2, python=F)

# Running python implementation on the most variable cell types.
# melanoma <- deconv_krige(melanoma, cells='top', who=2, python=T)
